DataElement.preferredName: Estrogen Receptor Level Minimum Nuclei Positive Percent Number
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value that represents the minimum percent Estrogen Receptor positive nuclei using the IHC method to determine a positive finding.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Widely expressed human Estrogen Receptors (NR3 Family) are ligand-activated nuclear hormone receptor transcription factors composed of an N-terminal transcription activation/modulation domain, a DNA-binding domain, and a C-terminal steroid-binding domain. Binding to DNA as a homo- or heterodimer, ESR interacts with NCOA3, NCOA5, and NCOA6 coactivators. Hormone-ESR complexes appear to recognize discrete upstream target ERE DNA sequences to regulate gene expression, cell proliferation, and differentiation. DNA-binding is lost in the absence of ligand. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: Widely expressed human Estrogen Receptors (NR3 Family) are cytoplasmic hormone-activated receptors that act as nuclear transcription factors composed of an N-terminal transcription activation/modulation domain, a DNA-binding domain, and a C-terminal steroid-binding domain. Binding to DNA as a homo- or heterodimer, ESR interacts with NCOA3, NCOA5, and NCOA6 coactivators. Hormone-ESR complexes appear to recognize discrete upstream target ERE DNA sequences to regulate gene expression, cell proliferation, and differentiation. DNA-binding is lost in the absence of ligand. (NCI)

Property.preferredDefinition: Level; a position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

Concepts.definition: A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The smallest possible quantity._Within a eukaryotic cell, a membrane-limited body which contains chromosomes and one or more nucleoli (CELL NUCLEOLUS). The nuclear membrane consists of a double unit-type membrane which is perforated by a number of pores; the outermost membrane is continuous with the ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM. A cell may contain more than one nucleus. (From Singleton & Sainsbury, Dictionary of Microbiology and Molecular Biology, 2d ed)_An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism._Percentage; a fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator._Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Minimum Nucleus Positive Finding Percentage Number
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The smallest possible quantity.:Within a eukaryotic cell, a membrane-limited body which contains chromosomes and one or more nucleoli (CELL NUCLEOLUS). The nuclear membrane consists of a double unit-type membrane which is perforated by a number of pores; the outermost membrane is continuous with the ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM. A cell may contain more than one nucleus. (From Singleton & Sainsbury, Dictionary of Microbiology and Molecular Biology, 2d ed):An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.:Percentage; a fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.:Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: A body within the cell, surrounded by a membrane, within which lie the chromosomes, one or more nucleoli, combined with proteins, and exhibits mitosis.
A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
A fraction or ratio with 100 understood as the denominator.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Released per approval by T.Lichtenberg. mc 8/16/11

ReferenceDocuments.name: What percent cut-off was used
ReferenceDocuments.description: What percent cut-off was used by the laboratory to clasify this case as ER positive or negative?
